data.title: Sweden signals continuation of ODA priorities
US Senate passes emergency funding bill, US$10 billion in humanitarian assistance
data.content:
**On February 13, 2024, the :abbr[US] Senate passed an US$95 billion emergency funding bill with funds for Ukraine, Israel, and Taiwan, with US$10 billion of the funding marked for humanitarian assistance.**\
\
The majority of the funding, US$85 million, was for military aid.\
\
The bill ultimately passed with bipartisan support. It has moved to the :abbr[US] House, where experts believe it will face great difficulties in securing approval. :abbr[NGOs] have rallied behind the bill, identifying critical needs in Ukraine, Gaza, and Sudan.\
\
If signed into law, assistance will go to humanitarian needs in Gaza, Ukraine, refugees in conflict areas, the World Bank's :abbr[IDA] special program for its crisis response window, and operating expenses.\
\
The :abbr[US] Speaker of the House has indicated that it is unlikely that the House will vote on the package, however, a small bipartisan group has been attempting to craft an alternative bill with a greater chance of approval.

data.title: Norwegian Church Aid calls for political parties to take greater development responsibility, initiative
Council of the EU foregrounds Ukraine, UNRWA at development meeting
data.content:
**On February 12, 2024, the Council of the :abbr[EU]'s ministers of development cooperation hosted an informal stocktake of :abbr[EU] development cooperation.**\
\
Hosted by the Belgian Council presidency, the meeting included an update on the :abbr[MFF] revision's additional funding to the Ukraine Facility. Additionally, the event included a session with Commissioner-General of the :abbr[UNRWA] Philippe Lazzarini.\
\
In response to allegations that :abbr[UNRWA] staff were involved in the October 7, 2023 Hamas attacks, [the EU paused](https://donortracker.org/policy_updates?policy=eu-commission-continues-assistance-to-unwra-2024) all additional assistance to :abbr[UNRWA] until the end of February 2024.\
\
Anticipating the possibility of the delay of [US$88 million](https://www.devex.com/news/un-aid-for-gaza-set-to-run-out-as-critical-88m-eu-payment-delayed-107067), Lazzarini highlighted the effect of withdrawn and frozen assistance on the organization's ability to continue supporting individuals in Gaza, stating that shortfalls could begin to impact initiatives starting in March 2024.\
\
Additionally, Lazzarini answered questions from the ministers regarding the state of investigations and the agency's plans to mitigate future risks. All Member States highlighted the need for increased support for Gazan civilians while underscoring the importance of the release of hostages and the rule of international and humanitarian law.

data.title: Italy launches US$196 million call for proposals for NGO, local authority projects
data.content:
**On February 12, 2024, :abbr[AICS], in partnership with :abbr[MAECI], launched a US$196 million (EUR180 million) call for proposals for projects led by :abbr[CSOs] and local Italian authorities.**\
\
US$130 million (EUR120 million) is slated for projects led by :abbr[CSOs]. US$66 million (EUR60 million) is slated for initiatives from Italy's regional and local authorities.\
\
The new grant is the highest-value call for development cooperation in this sector in recent years, and the first operational follow-up to Italy's [*Mattei Plan for Africa*](https://donortracker.org/policy_updates?policy=italys-meloni-announced-a-us-6-billion-mattei-plan-for-africa-2024).\
\
85% of the resources will be allocated to Africa. 15% is slated for other countries, including Ukraine.

sources.name: Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation

data.title: Netherlands provides US$2.2 billion guarantee to Ukraine
data.content:
**On February 9, 2024, the Dutch Council of Ministers approved a proposal of the Minister of Finance van Weyenberg to provide EUR2 billion (US$2.2 billion) to Ukraine in the form of a guarantee.**\
\
This proposal followed the :abbr[EU] support package, approved on February 1, 2024, to provide EUR50 billion (US$54.4 billion) to support the Ukrainian economy, government finances, and recovery and reform surrounding :abbr[EU] accession. Approximately EUR33 billion (US$35.9 billion) of the package will be loans and EUR17 billion (US$18.5 billion) will be delivered as grants.\
\
The Netherlands’ guarantee of EUR2 billion (US$2.2 billion) will be incorporated into the Dutch national budget. Calls on the guarantee will only take place if Ukraine proves unable to repay the loans to the European Commission.

data.title: Sweden launches new strategy to bolster democracy and support for human rights
data.content:
**On February 5, 2024, the Swedish Government announced the launch of a five-year strategy for enhancing development cooperation, with a budget of SEK900 million, (US$86 million) in 2024, centered on human rights, democracy, and the rule of law.**\
\
The plan represents a pivotal component of Sweden's broader :abbr[ODA] reform agenda and underscored the significance of democracy, human rights and freedoms, and the rule of law as essential principles for freedom, security and  societal progress in :abbr[ODA]. The new plan has arrived at a critical juncture for the development community, as democracy globally has faced a downward trend for the 17<sup>th</sup> year in a row, exemplified by crises such as the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022.\
\
The strategy contains enhanced support for human rights defenders, democratic processes, free elections, and independent journalism. The launch highlighted the increasing threat posed by authoritarian regimes that seek to erode basic human rights and employ digital technologies for suppression and to spread disinformation.\
\
Swedish Minister for International Development Cooperation and Foreign Trade Johan Forssell emphasized the strategy's focus on supporting individuals worldwide who tirelessly advocate for their freedoms under oppressive regimes.  Acknowledging the concerning trajectory of global democracy, Forssell expressed Sweden’s commitment to supporting those who champion democratic values and principles.

data.title: Council of the EU approves MFF revision; diverts assistance from NDICI
Japan sets out foreign policy, development strategy in speeches to the Diet
data.content:
**On January 30, 2024, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and Minister of Foreign Affairs Yoko Kamikawa laid out a strategy to strengthen Japan's role in addressing global challenges, promote sustainable development, and enhance infrastructure through strategic international cooperation and :abbr[ODA].**\
\
Kamikawa emphasized Japan's commitment to a free and open international order based on the Rule of Law, amid challenges including Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine and tensions in the Middle East. She noted that Japan aims to lead by example, advocating for peace and prosperity and ensuring that "human dignity" is protected worldwide, aligning with the core premise of the :abbr[SDGs], "Leave no one behind."\
\
Central to Japan's foreign policy is the strategic deployment of :abbr[ODA] to bolster its diplomatic efforts, promote human dignity, and address comprehensive global challenges including climate change, health security, and economic instability. Japan seeks to leverage :abbr[ODA] to enhance its global presence, contribute to international peace, and support the achievement of the :abbr[SDGs], highlighting its role in promoting sustainable development and infrastructure enhancement worldwide.\
\
Japan's foreign policy strategy underscored the importance of innovation and modern solutions in addressing international challenges. By integrating digital transformation, economic security initiatives, and modern technological solutions, Japan aims to enhance global health security frameworks, infrastructure resilience, and overall diplomatic effectiveness. This innovative approach is seen as vital for strengthening global partnerships and advancing a :abbr[FOIP]{title="Free and Open Indo-Pacific"}.\
\
Reaffirming commitment to rule of law, Kamikawa and Kishida noted that Japan is actively engaging with international courts and organizations to strengthen the global legal framework. Through the promotion of :abbr[FOIP]{title="Free and Open Indo-Pacific"}, Japan is working with allies and like-minded countries to ensure regional and global stability, emphasizing the importance of :abbr[ASEAN] and Quad collaborations, and seeking constructive relationships with neighboring countries, including with China and South Korea.\
\
The speeches marked a continuation of Japan's foreign policy approach to invest in :abbr[ODA] while making room for public-private partnerships to drive development around the world. The amicable and cooperative tone towards China and South Korea was welcomed by development advocates, with the hopes that regional solidarity will help address many of the ongoing major global issues.

sources.name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan

data.title: UK - Japan 21st Century Committee set to hold 40th joint meeting
data.content:
**The :ABBR[UK]-Japan 21<sup>st</sup> Century Committee is set to hold its 40<sup>th</sup> joint meeting from February 2-4, 2024, focusing on key topics including bilateral foreign policy, international security, climate change and energy, global health, and :abbr[AI].**\
\
This event continues the tradition of high-level dialogue and cooperation between the two nations. Originally established in 1985 by former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, the :ABBR[UK] - Japan 21<sup>st</sup> Century Group, formerly known as the :ABBR[UK] - Japan 2000 Group, serves as a vital platform for fostering mutual understanding and collaboration. Comprising leaders from the private sector, public sector, and civil society, the group’s annual conferences alternate between the :ABBR[UK] and Japan, addressing a wide range of critical issues from educational and cultural exchange to global security and economic policies.\
\
At the 39<sup>th</sup> joint meeting in January 2023, held at the University of East Anglia in the :abbr[UK], key discussions revolved around recent political and economic developments in both countries, global health challenges post-pandemic, and the evolving security landscape, particularly in light of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. The conference also delved into economic security, emphasizing the need for resilient supply chains and cooperation in the face of global economic disruptions. Cooperative dialogues, rooted in shared values and strategic interests, underscored the group’s ongoing commitment to enhancing the :ABBR[UK] - Japan partnership in various global contexts.

data.title: EU Commission pledges US$10.8 billion for Central Asian transport
data.content:
**On January 29, 2024, :abbr[EU] Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis launched the *[Investors Forum for EU-Central Asia Transport Connectivity.](https://international-partnerships.ec.europa.eu/news-and-events/investors-forum-eu-central-asia-transport-connectivity_en)***\
\
The event aimed to support discussions on the investments required to develop alternative trade flows between Europe and Central Asia in light of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\
\
Dombrovskis announced that the :abbr[EU] and :abbr[IFIs] would contribute EUR10 billion (US$10.8 billion) in the project. The event also included the signing of several memoranda of understanding between the :abbr[EIB] and partner countries including Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and Uzbekistan to support the development of transport infrastructure in the region.

data.title: UK think tank proposes ways to make ODA budget planning more predictable
data.content:
**On January 21, 2024, the :abbr[IFS]{title="International Institute for Fiscal Studies"} published a paper identifying three ways in which the :ABBR[UK] could improve its :ABBR[ODA] budget process to avoid high levels of uncertainty.**\
\
The :abbr[IFS]{title="International Institute for Fiscal Studies"} noted that at time of writing, the :ABBR[UK] :ABBR[ODA] budget is set with 0.5% :abbr[ODA/GNI] as a hard ceiling rather than a floor for spending. This has created :abbr[ODA] budget unpredictability, as the :abbr[UK] government has had to accurately forecast the cash size of the economy and then make in-year adjustments to ensure spending hits 0.5% :abbr[ODA/GNI] by the end of the year. The :abbr[IFS]{title="International Institute for Fiscal Studies"} stated that these unpredictable calculations, added to the unpredictability of other :abbr[ODA] spending needs such as :abbr[IDRC], which in 2022 amounted to 1/3 of :abbr[UK] :ABBR[ODA], can make it difficult for the :abbr[UK] government to plan the :ABBR[ODA] spend :abbr[ODA] effectively.\
\
The :abbr[IFS]{title="International Institute for Fiscal Studies"} proposed three changes to improve the predictability of the :ABBR[UK] :ABBR[ODA] budget process, which included: 

- Establishing a :ABBR[ODA] reserve to respond to meet unexpected demands, such as :abbr[IDRC], or world events, such as the full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The :abbr[IFS]{title="International Institute for Fiscal Studies"} also suggested that could be achieved by putting aside a fixed share (10-20%) of the budget each year for these costs, or by the agreeing to allow the :ABBR[ODA] budget to rise beyond 0.5% :abbr[ODA/GNI] (to approximately 0.55- 0.6%) in exceptional circumstances. While either of these suggestions, or a combination of the two, would require rolling targets and adjustments to ensure that funding can be recouped or spent appropriately in the future, the :abbr[IFS]{title="International Institute for Fiscal Studies"} stated that these strategies would enable more programs to be protected from in-year cuts due to unforeseen spending;  

- Basing the :ABBR[ODA] budget is based on the national income of the previous year, with an allowance for expected economic growth. The :abbr[IFS]{title="International Institute for Fiscal Studies"} noted that lagging calculations of the :ABBR[ODA] budget would avoid having to track and adjust :abbr[ODA] to in-year fluctuations of national income.  In the case of an economic crash, :abbr[ODA]cuts would first be made the following year, leaving adequate time to plan and adjust :abbr[ODA] programs; and

- Performing fiscal tests that assess the possibility of returning to 0.7% :abbr[ODA/GNI] in the third year of an economic forecast. The :abbr[IFS]{title="International Institute for Fiscal Studies"} suggested that the results would then be treated as a given and enable a gradual ramping up of spending over 3 years. This would avoid the large hikes in the :abbr[ODA] that make spending planning difficult.

data.title: Netherlands pledges US$16 million to humanitarian efforts in Ukraine
data.content:
**On January 15, 2024, the Netherlands pledged an additional EUR15 million (US$16 million) to the Ukraine Humanitarian Fund to assist war-affected communities, including refugees and host communities in the region.**\
\
 The pledge is in addition to the EUR10 million (US$11 million) the Dutch government has previously pledged for high-quality and accessible psychosocial support.\
 \
The Netherlands announced this at the Joint Launch of the Humanitarian Response Plan and the Regional Refugee Response Plan for Ukraine in Geneva. The plan estimates that US$3.1 billion is needed to meet the humanitarian needs in and around Ukraine.

data.title: UNDP and Japan announce plans for energy infrastructure in Ukraine
data.content:
**On January 8, 2024, in Kyiv, Ukraine, the :abbr[UNDP] in Ukraine and the Government of Japan jointly announced the delivery of three state-of-the-art gas turbines and assistance in transporting seven autotransformers to Ukraine.**\
\
This initiative, in coordination with Ukraine's Ministry of Energy, aims to address the urgent needs of Ukraine's energy sector for the winter of 2024 and aligns with the country's long-term national goals. The autotransformers, purchased by the Ukrainian company Ukrenergo with funds from the :abbr[EBRD], is slated to bolster Ukaine's energy infrastructure.\
\
Russian attacks on Ukraine’s energy infrastructure in the winter of 2022 drastically reduced Ukraine's power generation capacity by half and disrupted essential services for approximately 93% of Ukrainians. The provision of the gas turbines and the transportation of the autotransformers is intended to prevent further disruptions in the winter of 2024, ensuring vital services for over 5.5 million people in affected regions. Additionally, the equipment aligns with Ukraine's goals for decentralization and transitioning to a green energy sector by incorporating biohydrogen fuel use.\
\
The equipment handover ceremony was attended by Japan's Minister of Foreign Affairs who reaffirmed Japan's commitment to supporting Ukraine, particularly in restoring its energy infrastructure and enduring the winter. Ukraine’s Minister of Energy expressed gratitude for the ongoing support from Japan and the :abbr[UNDP], emphasizing its significance in these challenging times. The ministers noted that initiative represented a collaborative effort to not only address immediate needs but also to lay the foundation for a more sustainable and resilient energy sector in Ukraine.

data.title: South Korea approves US$3.3 billion for 2024 Foreign Affairs budget
data.content:
**On December 21, 2023, the South Korean National Assembly allocated KRW4.2 trillion (US$3.3 billion) for its 2024 :abbr[MOFA] budget.**\
\
This is an increase of 24.8% (KRW832.5 billion (US$645 million)) compared to 2023. However, it is a net decline of KRW99 billion (US$77 million) from the initially proposed 2024 budget.\
\
The humanitarian assistance budget has been significantly expanded from KRW299.3 billion (US$232 million) in 2023 to US$573 million (KRW740.1 billion) in 2024. The increase is meant to support innovation and development and cope with humanitarian crises, such as the prolonged war in Ukraine and other disasters.

data.title: Netherlands launches US$111 million 2024 support package to Ukraine
data.content:
**On December 21, 2023, the Netherlands launched its first support package of 2024 to Ukraine, totaling EUR102 million (US$111 million) and aimed at providing urgent needs to help Ukraine get through winter and prepare for spring.**\ \ On December 15, 2023, Dutch Minister for Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation Geoffrey van Leeuwen announced intentions for the package during a visit to Ukraine. The package's allocations were: - EUR62 million (US$67 million) to support the Ukrainian Government in delivering basic services, restoring critical infrastructure, and ensuring reforms through the Special Program for Ukraine and Moldova Recovery, part of the :abbr[IDA] of the World Bank; - EUR15 million (US$16 million) for humanitarian assistance via :abbr[UNOCHA]’s Ukraine Humanitarian Fund; - EUR15 million (US$16 million) for the demining of agricultural lands and liberated areas; and - EUR10 million (US$11 million) in supplies for the Ukrainian electricity network.
The package is part of more than EUR2 billion (US$2.2 billion) that the Netherlands has reserved for support to Ukraine in 2024. Of this, EUR2 billion (US$2.2 billion) will go towards military support, EUR295 million (US$212 million) towards the European Peace Facility, EUR89 million (US$97 million) to combat impunity, and EUR3 million (US$3.3 million) for non-military cyber support.

data.title: Sweden announces new ODA framework
data.content:
**On December 19, 2023, the right-wing Swedish Government, comprising moderates, liberals and Christian Democrats, in collaboration with the right-wing populist Sweden Democrats, unveiled a new strategic framework for the country's development assistance.**\
\
Titled *Development assistance for a new era – freedom, empowerment and sustainable growth*, the reform agenda is set to recalibrate Sweden's approach to international :abbr[ODA], infusing it with a focus on sustainability, transparency, and efficacy.\
\
Swedish Minister for International Development Cooperation and Foreign Trade Johan Forssell, from the Moderate Party, expressed pride in the reform, which he noted integrated development assistance with trade. Forssell stated that the new approach will leverage Swedish corporate strengths in sustainability and social responsibility, aiming to address societal challenges through investments and innovation.\
\
The reform marked a critical juncture in Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which has had far-reaching political, economic, and humanitarian implications. Prioritizing Ukraine and its surroundings, the new strategy has a stated aim to alleviate poverty through job creation and free trade, enhance humanitarian assistance, promote freedom, oppose oppression, and create synergies between development assistance and migration policies. The policy seeks to augment climate assistance, empower women and girls, and improve health and educational quality for the vulnerable.\
\
Chair of the Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs Aron Emilsson, from the Sweden Democrats, highlighted the policy's historic nature, emphasizing its dual focus on the promotion of Swedish interests and humanitarian assistance. He highlighted that the new  policy is envisaged as a foreign policy tool to facilitate the elimination of impediments to enforcement of expulsions of illegal immigrants and combating human trafficking.\
\
Development Policy Spokesperson for the Christian Democrats Gudrun Brunegård noted the increased support for :abbr[CSOs], vital for tangible change and support to the most needy and vulnerable.\
\
Acknowledging that no country has overcome poverty solely through international assistance, the Government emphasized stimulating economic growth and trade in partner countries. The approach underlined the necessity of focusing Swedish development cooperation on areas of distinct Swedish expertise and value addition.\
\
Foreign Policy Spokesperson of the Liberal Party Joar Forssell pointed out the agenda's heightened focus on the promotion of democracy and human rights, alongside efforts to combat gender inequality, will play a crucial role in promoting freedom around the world and shape Sweden's proactive stance towards fostering a freer global society.

data.title: Potential MFF midterm revision prioritizes Ukraine, migration
data.content:
**On December 15, 2023, 26 members of the European Council agreed upon an EUR64.6 billion (US$69.9 billion) midterm revision to the bloc's [Mulitannual Financial Framework.](https://donortracker.org/publications/donor-budget-basics-the-eus-mff-2023), with Hungary's veto blocking the agreement.**\
\
The additional funding package comprised a significant decrease from the Commission's June 2023 proposal of an [EUR74.5 billion](https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_23_3345) (US$80.6 billion) increase. If approved in the upcoming year, the agreement would significantly reduce  proposed new funding for external action endorsed by the European Commission and backed by the European Parliament, and would shift focus towards investment in migration management. Funding for migration management would come from a combination of newly allocated funds and reallocating existing resources from programs such as development and health, among others.\
\
Proposed funding for Ukraine remained robust, receiving EUR50 billion (US$54.1 billion) in grants and loans, in line with the June 2023 proposal. However, migration and humanitarian assistance decreased, falling to EUR9.6 billion (US$10.4 billion) and EUR1.5 billion (US$1.6 billion) from the June proposal's EUR12.5 billion (US$13.5 billion) and EUR2.5 billion (US$2.7 billion), respectively.\
\
Increased interest rates on :abbr[EU] borrowing, in addition to pressures from the war in Ukraine and budgetary challenges in Member States, continue to stress :abbr[EU] expenditures.\
\
A European Council is scheduled at the beginning of February to discuss the future of the agreement and vote on potential changes.

data.title: Netherlands pledges US$19 million for Ukraine justice
data.content:
**On December 5, 2023, during a visit to Kyiv, Dutch Minister for Foreign Affairs Hanke Bruins Slot announced a commitment of EUR17 million (US$19 million) to combat impunity and achieve justice for Ukrainian victims of war crimes.**\
\
The funds consisted of two parts. EUR9 million (US$10 million) will go towards the project ‘Restoring Dignity and Justice in Ukraine’, to support the judicial sector with knowledge, expertise, and capacity, especially in the field of international criminal law. The remaining EUR8 million (US$9 million) will go towards the civilian European Union Advisory Mission. The funds are meant to help strengthen the public prosecutor’s office and the police in liberated areas and to advise on investigation and prosecution.\
\
During the minister’s visit, the Secretariat of the Dialogue Group on Accountability of Ukraine was opened at the Prosecutor General in Kyiv. The Netherlands initiated the group as a platform for countries, international organizations, and civil society stakeholders to align national and international justice initiatives.\
\
Previously, in October 2022, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy presented a ten-point Peace Plan for Ukraine. According to a news article, the Netherlands took the lead within the international community on point number seven “restoring justice”.

data.title: Norway announces US$23 million for food security in Ukraine
data.content:
**On November 25, 2023, Norway pledged NOK200 million (US$19 million) to the :abbr[WFP] to support food security in Ukraine, including through the humanitarian food program *Grain from Ukraine*.**\
\
The announcement was presented during the Second International Summit on Food Security in Kiev, Ukraine. Norway also pledged NOK50 million (US$5 million) to the World Bank's :abbr[URTF].\
\
Minister of Foreign Affairs Espen Barth Eide underlined that Norway, particularly its Nansen Program, stands firmly by Ukraine. He emphasized that Norway had also not lost sight of the other global crises.

data.title: European leaders call for reduced MFF allocations
data.content:
**On November 23, 2023,  it was reported that the Swedish Presidency of the Council of the :abbr[EU] presented three draft revisions to the Commission's EUR66 billion (US$72 billion) June 2023 proposal and proposed alternative paths totaling EUR61 billion (US$65.9 billion), EUR56 billion (US$60.5 billion), and EUR46 billion (US$49.7 billion).**\
\
As :abbr[EUi] institutions negotiate the Commission's [proposed increases](https://donortracker.org/policy_updates?policy=eu-commission-proposes-mff-revisions) to the bloc's :abbr[MFF], a seven-year budgeting tool, European leaders have urged the bloc to reduce its planned spending.\
\
Citing the tension of net-contributer countries financing the projects of net-recipient countries, as well as pressures from COVID-19 spending and the war in Ukraine, some officials argued that spending should be reigned in by at least 20%.\
\
:abbr[MFF] negotiations are expected to continue through the meeting of the European Council in December 2023.

data.title: Italy approves ODA allocations, initiatives, additional resources for Ukraine and Palestine
data.content:
**On November 22, 2023, the Italian Joint Development Cooperation Committee approved additional resources to mitigate the effects of war on Ukrainian and Palestinian civilians, totalling EUR17 million (US$18 million) for Ukraine and EUR5 million (US$5 million) for Palestine.**\ \ The committee also approved a package of initiatives, including EUR8 million (US$8.7 million) for Africa, focusing on food security, health, education, and training aimed at professional improvement.\ \ Resources for Tunisia were approved at a total of EUR3 million (US$3 million) for 2024, an increase compared to 2023 programming. Italy has emphasized Tunisia as a priority partner.\ \ The committee voted to approve the channeled allocation of EUR998 million (US$1 billion) in funds for development cooperation initiatives in 2024. The allocations detailed: - EUR537 million (US$586 million) to bilateral cooperation; - EUR271 million(US$295 million) to emergency funding; and - EUR190 million (US$207 million) to multilateral cooperation.
The committee also approved a contribution of EUR2 million(US$2 million) for the Balkan region to strengthen disaster preparedness and response capacities in Bosnia and Herzegovina.\ \ Finally, the Committee gave a favorable opinion on two initiatives proposed by Cassa Depositi e Prestiti, which included: - Financing projects related to the agricultural and agribusiness supply chain through the West African Development Bank; and - Refinancing of a line of credit in Latin America and the Caribbean in support of investments in the environmental sector and the fight against climate change.

data.title: Japan addresses climate change, digital governance, women-led development at G20
data.content:
**On November 22, 2023, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida participated in the :abbr[G20] Leaders' Video Conference in India, and discussed crucial global issues including multilateral reforms, climate change, digital governance, and women-led development.**\
\
Kishida acknowledged Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's leadership and welcomed the African Union as a permanent :abbr[G20] member. He highlighted the complexity of global crises, emphasizing Russia's aggression against Ukraine as a threat to sustainable development.\
\
Addressing multilateral system reforms, Kishida stressed the need to strengthen the :abbr[UN], including Security Council reform. He proposed enhancing the functions of multilateral development banks to support developing countries facing global challenges. Kishida also called for increased efforts to limit temperature rise, urging all parties to commit to net-zero emissions by 2050 and ambitious emission reduction targets.\
\
In the digital sphere, Kishida emphasized the importance of international governance for :abbr[AI], introducing Japan's efforts through the Hiroshima :abbr[AI] Process. He expressed Japan's commitment to promoting safe and secure :abbr[AI] globally.\
\
Kishida also underscored the need to close the gender gap and enhance women's participation across all sectors. He outlined Japan's commitment to shedding light on "human dignity" under Brazil's upcoming :abbr[G20] Presidency, pledging continued contributions to global cooperation in addressing diverse challenges.

sources.name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan

data.title: Japanese delegation visits Ukraine ahead of reconstruction talks
data.content:
**On November 20, 2023, a Japanese delegation led by senior officials from industry and the foreign ministry visited Ukraine ahead of an upcoming reconstruction conference hosted by Japan.**\
\
The delegation included representatives from major Japanese companies and engaged in discussions in Kyiv with Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal and Ukrainian officials.\
\
Shmyhal emphasized Ukraine's urgent need for approximately US$42 billion in budget support for 2023 and 2024 to address a substantial deficit and support Ukrainian reconstruction efforts. The visit provided a platform for Japanese officials and businesses to learn about Ukraine's specific needs, foster discussions on potential projects, and expedite public and private collaborative efforts for reconstruction.\
\
The visit underscored Japan's ongoing commitment to support Ukraine, aligning with its multifaceted approach to international development. Japan also supported the reopening of the :abbr[JICA] Ukraine office in November 2023, with plans to facilitate projects in agriculture, education, and industry. These efforts complemented earlier commitments, such as Japan's US$471 million donation to the World Bank's Ukraine Relief Fund in April 2023 and the announcement of grant assistance projects totaling US$470 million in March 2023, which focused on recovery and reconstruction efforts.

data.title: South Korea hosts 2023 World Bio Summit
data.content:
**From November 20-21, 2023, South Korea co-hosted the 2<sup>nd</sup> World Bio Summit with the :abbr[WHO] to discuss building pandemic preparedness and response systems, featuring representatives from national governments, the scientific community, the private sector, and international organizations in the vaccine and biofields.**\
\
The summit invited representatives from the :abbr[ADB], :abbr[CEPI], :abbr[IVI], and :abbr[FIND].\
\
South Korean 2<sup>nd</sup> Vice Minister of Health and Welfare Min-soo Park held a meeting with Saudi Arabia, Ukraine, Laos, :abbr[CEPI], and the  :abbr[WHO]. Representatives held in-depth discussions on expanding the capabilities of vaccine production and development at the government, corporate, and international organization levels. In particular, the :abbr[KDCA] pledged to expand its cooperation on pandemic response with :abbr[Gavi] and :abbr[UKHSA].

sources.name: Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency

data.title: Netherlands reserves US$2.2 billion in support Ukraine from 2024 budget
data.content:
**On November 17, 2023, the Dutch Ministers of Defense, Foreign Affairs, and Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation announced that the Dutch government has reserved EUR2 billion (US$2.2 billion) for military and humanitarian support for Ukraine in 2024, including EUR102 million (US$111 million) for critical infrastructure, humanitarian assistance, and demining.**\
\
The Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs noted that this pledge follows the Netherlands’ commitment made at the July 2023 :abbr[NATO] Summit to continue its long-term support for Ukraine. In 2022, the Netherlands similarly reserved EUR2.5 billion (US$2.7 billion), of which EUR1.7 billion (US$1.8 billion) was slated for intensified military support.\
\
While most of the 2024 funds are reserved for military support, EUR102 million (US$111 million) is reserved for the first four months of 2024 for humanitarian support, recovery, and reconstruction. After these four months, the government will update its financial support based on expressed needs.\
\
The Netherlands also reserved EUR89 million (US$97 million) for accountability, including housing a special Ukraine tribunal in the future, and EUR3 million (US$3 million) for bolstering Ukrainian cybersecurity.

data.title: Sweden pledges US$7 million to rebuild Ukrainian educational infrastructure
data.content:
**On November 17, 2023, in response to the devastating impact of Russia's 2022 full-scale invasion of Ukraine, which has led to the damage or destruction of over 3000 educational facilities, the Swedish government pledged SEK75 million (US$7 million) to the :abbr[UNESCO] Emergency Fund to renovate and reconstruct Ukranian educational facilities**\
\
This contribution is part of Sweden's broader development assistance to Ukraine, which has totaled over SEK3 billion (US$290 million) since the current government took office in 2021. The pledge is a direct response to the Ukrainian Ministry of Education and Science's request for assistance in rebuilding the education sector.\
\
Sweden's contribution aims to enable thousands of Ukrainian children and students to resume in-person education and activities crucial for their social and mental well-being. The support is additionally slated to address the need for functioning shelters, which play a vital role in enabling parents to work while children are in school.\
\
Swedish Minister for Schools Lotta Edholm emphasized the importance of ensuring that education continues without significant interruptions and that schools and preschools remain safe havens for children. The Swedish contribution will facilitate the installation of essential facilities for :abbr[WASH] services, heating, and insulation, as well as ensuring accessibility and providing psychosocial support and physical activities for children.

data.title: South Korea attends high-level DAC meeting, highlights partnerships
data.content:
**On November 15, 2023, South Korean Deputy Minister for Multilateral and Global Affairs Ki-hwan Kwon attended the 53<sup>th</sup> high-level meeting of the :abbr[OECD] :abbr[DAC].**\
\
Partner countries, World Bank representatives, :abbr[CSOs], and :abbr[DAC] member states discussed the expansion of the :abbr[DAC] partnership, securing funding for the implementation of the :abbr[SDGs], and the impact of geopolitical challenges on development assistance. Kwon highlighted the need for the :abbr[DAC] states to strengthen partnerships with entities including partner countries, :abbr[CSOs], international organizations, and private enterprises. He emphasized the importance of actively leveraging comparative advantages and supporting the achievement of the :abbr[SDGs] in the international community.\
\
Member states adopted a communiqué recognizing unprecedented global crises such as climate change, the COVID-19 pandemic, and the war of aggression in Ukraine. Leaders committed to continuing global solidarity to meet increasing demand for humanitarian assistance while promoting resilient, sustainable, and balanced development.

data.title: Norway increases support to humanitarian partners in Ukraine
data.content:
**On November 13, 2023, the Norwegian Government announced that it will allocate NOK1 billion (US$90 million) to the Norwegian Refugee Council, Norwegian Red Cross, Norwegian Church Aid, Norwegian People's Aid, Save the Children, :abbr[NORCAP]{title="Norwegian Capacity"}, and Caritas Norway.**\
\
The funding is slated to help Ukrainians that have lost their homes through shelter and :abbr[WASH] services, as well as education and healthcare.\
\
 Norwegian Minister of Foreign Affairs Espen Barth Eide noted that Norway, in line with its *Nansen program for Ukraine*, will continue to provide emergency assistance and protection to millions of Ukrainians living under perilous conditions.\
 \
Norway has contributed over NOK4.5 billion (US$406 million) in humanitarian assistance to Ukraine and refugee response in neighboring countries since 2022. The assistance is channeled primarily through the :abbr[UN], the Red Cross movement, and Norwegian and international humanitarian organizations.\
\
The organizations receiving support have multi-year strategic partnership agreements with the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The newly launched funding was allocated through the multi-year *Nansen program for Ukraine*, which is managed by :abbr[Norad].

data.title: Norwegian opposition presents alternative 2024 state budget
data.content:
**On November 9, 2023, the opposition Norwegian :abbr[SV] presented its highly anticipated alternative state budget for 2024 to negotiate with the current minority government.**\
\
It is common for opposition parties to draft alternative budgets before state budget negotiations begin in Parliament.\
\
:abbr[SV] spokesperson on international development Ingrid Fiskaa highlighted the need for a revised international development budget from the government in an interview with the Norwegian newspaper *Panorama*. She asserted that Norway must step up its international development ambitions, especially as Norway is generating large revenues from oil and gas sales. She made particular note of the current government's budget draft failing to meet the 1% :abbr[ODA/GNI] target.\
\
However, :abbr[SV] party leader Kjersti Bergstø stated in an interview with *Vårt Land* that the :abbr[SV] does not see the 1% :abbr[ODA/GNI] target as a priority. She noted her belief that the government, not the opposition, should be responsible for achieving the target. Her comments received criticism from the opposition Liberal Party and the Christian Democratic Party, who noted that in times of severe global crises, it is disappointing that the :abbr[SV] is not prioritizing international development.\
\
In the alternative state budget, the :abbr[SV] allocated an additional NOK8 billion (US$722 million) to the development budget. The budget also provided for the continuation of extra funding to :abbr[LICs] particularly affected by the consequences of the war in Ukraine.\
\
The following increases were included in the alternative budget:
- Human rights and civil society: NOK1550 million (US$139 million);
- Palestinian refugees (via the UN organization UNRWA): NOK150 million (US$13.5 million);
- Decentralized, small-scale renewable energy solutions: NOK220 million (US$20 million);
- Long-term assistance to the Middle East, Myanmar, Afghanistan, and Latin America: NOK190 million (US$17 million);
- Education: NOK100 million (US$9 million); and
- Support for Norwegian organizations' work against nuclear weapons: NOK10 million (US$903,000).

data.title: JICA resumes operations at Ukraine office
data.content:
**On November 1, 2023, the Japanese government announced the reopening of the :abbr[JICA] Ukraine office.**\
\
The office had been closed since the January 2022 lead-up to the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine. Staff from the office have since been working from neighboring countries.\
\
:abbr[JICA] is responsible for over US$1.1 billion of assistance provided by Japan. It noted plans to use its Kyiv office to facilitate projects in the areas of agriculture, education, and industry. The organization will increase its presence in Ukraine and is expected to commence fully-fledged operations next year.

data.title: AidWatch 2023 report finds EU inflates ODA by 22%
data.content:
**On October 18, 2023, :abbr[Concord]{title="European Confederation of NGOs working on sustainable development and international cooperation"} released its 2023 AidWatch Report and found that EUR20 billion (US$21.2 billion), or 22% of :abbr[ODA] from the :abbr[EU] and its Member States, was allocated to budget lines that do not directly benefit partner countries.**\ \ Concord has published AidWatch Reports annually since 2005 in an effort to provide accountability for the :abbr[EU] and its Member States in meeting the goal of providing 0.7% :abbr[GNI/ODA].\ \ Examining :abbr[EU] and Member State :abbr[ODA] in 2022, the report found that of the :abbr[ODA] that did not directly benefit partner countries, the three largest categories of "double counted" or "inflated" :abbr[ODA] included: - EUR13.9 billion (US$14.7 billion) went to in-donor refugee costs to for those fleeing the war in Ukraine, allocations which are at times reported as :abbr[ODA] at the Member State level; - EUR2.8 billion (US$3 billion) supported imputed student costs, or funding for students from partner countries studying in the donor country; and - EUR1.7 billion resulting from a method of calculating and reporting :abbr[ODA] loans as grants, which distorted the actual value of the support.
Accounting for inflated :abbr[ODA], the report found that only two Member States, Luxembourg and Sweden, met the 0.7% :abbr[ODA/GNI] ratio, while Germany's ratio fell to near .69%.\ \ The report noted that these observations comprised the continuation of skewed reporting trends in the :abbr[EU] and Member States. It recommended increasing :abbr[ODA] spending to meet the goal of 0.7% :abbr[ODA/GNI], not counting in-donor refugee costs as :abbr[ODA], and reforming :abbr[ODA] reporting to ensure assistance achieves maximum impact, among others.

data.title: Sweden pledges US$28 million to bolster Moldova's energy infrastructure
data.content:
**On October 17, 2023,  Sweden committed EUR26 million (US$28 million) to strengthen Moldova's energy provisions, aiming to safeguard Moldova’s most vulnerable households during the winter and invest in the country's long-term energy infrastructure and efficiency.**\
\
Minister for International Development Cooperation and Foreign Trade Johan Forssell noted the severe impact of Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine on Moldova's infrastructure and stability.\
\
EUR17 million (US$18 million) of the funding is earmarked for the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to augment its initiatives in Moldova. The remaining EUR9 million (US$10 million) will be allocated to an energy fund set up by Moldova and the :abbr[UNDP] to assist high-risk households during the winter.\
\
Sweden has maintained a strong history of support to Moldova as one of its primary bilateral development assistance donors. Sweden has previously provided close to EUR17 million (US$18 million) in 2023 for ongoing reform initiatives in Moldova as part of Moldova's growing alignment with the :abbr[EU]. The initiatives aimed to prioritize democracy, human rights, gender equality, peaceful development, market economic progression, and ecological and climate sustainability.

data.title: Netherlands pledges US$109 million for MNCH
data.content:
**On October 16, 2023, the Netherlands pledged EUR100 million (US$109 million) towards :abbr[MNCH] at the :abbr[GFF]'s :abbr[WHS] pledging event.**\
\
Dutch Vice Minister for International Cooperation Pascalle Grotenhuis announced that the Netherlands will triple its annual contribution to the :abbr[GFF] to EUR90 million (US$98 million). The Netherlands pledged to provide a top-up of EUR10 million (US$11 million) to support the rebuilding of Ukraine’s health systems.\
\
A press release by the :abbr[GFF] stated that governments and philanthropies committed a total of US$445 million in funding to strengthen primary healthcare and to improve the health and rights of women and children. This event was the first pledging opportunity of the ‘Deliver the Future’ campaign, launched in June 2023 and co-hosted by the Netherlands, Germany, Côte d’Ivoire, and the World Bank.

data.title: Norway pledges to strengthen social safety nets in low-income countries
data.content:
**On October 13, 2023, during the World Banks's Annual Meetings in Marrakech, the Norwegian government announced a NOK100 million (US$9 million) pledge to the World Bank's work on strengthening the social safety nets in :abbr[LICs] affected by the war in Ukraine.**\
\
Norwegian Minister of International Development Anne Beathe Tvinnereim noted that the funding will help increase the use of cash transfers and other forms of support for families affected by hunger and food insecurity. She emphasized that social safety nets contribute to family resilience and are important tools in long-term work to reduce poverty and inequality.\
\
The Norwegian funding will be allocated through the World Bank's multi-donor :abbr[RSR-ADSP]{title="Rapid Social Response - Adaptive and Dynamic Social Protection"}. 50% of funding is financed through the Nansen program, the Norwegian funding package addressing the war in Ukraine. A portion of the funding is slated to be allocated to :abbr[LICs] severely affected by the war. A renewed involvement in the :abbr[RSR-ADSP]{title="Rapid Social Response - Adaptive and Dynamic Social Protection"} additionally aligns with the Norwegian government's strategy related to food safety. The Norwegian funding is planned to support projects on food safety and nutrition.\
\
Norway previously supported the :abbr[RSR-ADSP]{title="Rapid Social Response - Adaptive and Dynamic Social Protection"} fund with NOK130 million (US$13 million). Other notable donors are the :abbr[UK], Australia, Sweden, Denmark, :abbr[USAID], the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Germany and Russia.

data.title: Italy announces 60% bilateral cooperation increase for 2024
data.content:
**On October 9, 2023, the Italian Joint Committee for International Development decided to raise resources allocated to bilateral cooperation by 60% in 2024, with  25% and 15% of remaining resources for 2024 to be given to emergency and multilateral interventions, respectively.**\
\
Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation Antonio Tajani stated that Africa will be the priority areas for Italy. Bilateral projects are slated to focus mainly on income-generating sectors, such as support for startups and :abbr[SMEs], energy transitions, and vocational training in Africa.\
\
The committee also approved the allocation of more than EUR300 million (US$318 million) in grants to Egypt, Sudan, Kenya, Mali, Niger, Somalia, and the Central African Republic, and in aid credits to Ethiopia. It noted a voluntary contribution to the :abbr[OECD] to establish an investment observatory for Africa.\
\
The committee further approved a EUR180 million (US$190 million) call for proposals for :abbr[NGOs]. 85% of the resources were slated by the committee to be concentrated on projects in Africa.\
\
Tajani noted the approval of an additional contribution to Ukraine and a contribution to the Food Systems Transformation Fund, launched at the :abbr[UN] Summit on Food Systems hosted by Italy in July 2022. The donation was earmarked for the :abbr[IOM]{title="International Organization for Migration"} to combat human trafficking and further the voluntary repatriation of migrants and refugees to their areas of origin.\
\
Finally, the committee expressed approval of the Italian development bank Cassa Depositi e Prestiti's refinancing of two credit lines, which were opened with two :abbr[MDBs] in Africa for up to EUR300 million  (US$318 million).

sources.name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation

data.title: Netherlands delivers US$111 million in support to Ukraine
data.content:
**On October 6, 2023, Dutch Minister for Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation Liesje Schreinemacher outlined the Netherlands' third 2023 support package for Ukraine, noting that the Dutch government will provide EUR102 million (US$111 million) for humanitarian assistance, recovery, and reconstruction.**\
\
The support package follows the government’s decision in December 2022 to earmark EUR2.5 billion (US$2.7 billion) to support Ukraine in 2023. The first support package of EUR274 million (US$294 million) in April 2023 went partly towards non-lethal support to Ukraine’s armed forces. The second support package of EUR119 million (US$127 million) in July 2023 was focused on humanitarian assistance, recovery, and reconstruction.\
\
The third support package of EUR102 million (US$111 million) is focused on non-military support, in line with the most recent Ukraine Rapid Damage and Needs Assessment of Ukrainian authorities, the World Bank, and the European Commission. It contained the following three priority funding lines:

- Energy security (EUR30 million (US$33 million)): EUR20 million (US$22 million) for gas purchases through the :abbr[EBRD] and EUR10 million (US$11 million) for in-kind supplies for the energy network through the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy;
- Reconstruction through the Dutch private sector (EUR60 million (US$65 million)): EUR60 million (US$65 million) to enable an :abbr[EKV]{title="export credit insurance"} worth EUR120 million (US$131 million) to cover financial risks for Dutch companies that contribute to the reconstruction of Ukraine; and 
- Institution building (EUR12 million (US$13 million)): EUR7 million (US$8 million) for technical assistance from the :abbr[IMF] to help Ukraine implement financial and economic reforms under the :abbr[IMF] Reform Program for Ukraine. EUR5 million (US$5 million) for Ukrainian local authorities through the :abbr[PFRU]{title="Partnership Fund for Resilient Ukraine"} to repair drinking water facilities, electricity, primary healthcare services, and education.

sources.name: Letter to the Dutch House of Representatives

data.title: Norway releases proposed 2024 development budget, fails to achieve 1% ODA/GNI
data.content:
**On October 6, 2023, the Norwegian government presented its proposed state budget for 2024, which indicated an international development budget of NOK51.7 billion (US$4.7 billion), corresponding to 0.94% of estimated 2024 :abbr[GNI].**\
\
With many low-income countries facing the compounding crises of war, climate change, and food insecurity, anticipation for Norway's international development budget has been high. In Norway, there is a cross-party consensus that the yearly :abbr[ODA] funding should amount to 1% :abbr[ODA/GNI]. Norway's state budget for 2023 planned to reduce the :abbr[ODA] budget to 0.75% :abbr[ODA/GNI], however, due to an Ukraine funding package and budget negotiations with the :abbr[SV], the government managed to reach its previous commitment of 1% :abbr[ODA/GNI] in 2023. \
\
Norwegian Minister of International Development Anne Beathe Tvinnereim underlined that the total proposed 2024 budget amounted to an absolute increase of NOK7.5 billion (US$684 million) compared to the balanced 2023 budget, which marks it as the second-largest budget for international development to ever be proposed. Tvinnereim asserted that although the 1% :abbr[ODA/GNI] goal was not achieved, the budget accurately reflects the needs of low-income partner countries and Ukraine. When :abbr[ODA] is measured in terms of :abbr[ODA/GNI], Norway continues to be among the largest funders of global development.

data.title: US House votes to slash foreign assistance
data.content:
**On September 28, 2023, the :abbr[US] House of Representatives voted to cut :abbr[US] foreign assistance by 12%, passing its version of the State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs appropriations bill.**\
\
The debate included a number of amendments to drastically cut funding to :ABBR[USAID] and other development efforts. The bill is widely viewed by experts as unlikely to move any further.\
\
The vote came as the :abbr[US] Congress struggled to pass a Continuing Resolution to keep the government running beyond the end of the fiscal year, which was narrowly achieved hours before the deadline of September 30, 2023. The resolution maintained current funding levels, but notably did not contain any funding for Ukraine.\
\
The debate marked a significant departure from the bipartisan support that :abbr[US] foreign assistance has enjoyed for more than a decade. Some amendments, led by an ultra-conservative section of the Republican Party, sought to cut funding to :ABBR[USAID], eliminate humanitarian assistance, cut all funding to Ukraine, eliminate funding for implementation of the Paris Accord, and introduce other funding cuts and constraints. The :abbr[US] Senate is not expected to support these amendments.\
\
The House and Senate face a deadline in mid-November to resolve significant differences between House and Senate spending levels. Funding lines up for debate include spending on Ukraine, climate adaptation, and multilateral institutions.\
\
 :ABBR[USAID] remains open to make new commitments and hires. The process of getting approval from Congress on spending particulars during the negotiations, however, would likely lead to months-long delays on new initiatives.

data.title: Sweden outlines development priorities
data.content:
**On September 23, 2023, Swedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billström presented Sweden's development priority statement at the 78<sup>th</sup> :abbr[UN] General Assembly.**\
\
In a speech predominantly centered on Ukraine, Billström emphasized Russia's tactics of weaponizing food, exacerbating the global food crisis. He pointed out Russia's recent imposition of its blockade against grain shipments across the Black Sea, which is restricting food supplies to many, including some of the world's most vulnerable populations.\
\
Sweden underscored the need for the :abbr[UN] to persistently seek enhanced effectiveness and efficiency, particularly at the national level. Billström called for development assistance to work synergistically with trade, private investment, improved access to capital, and domestic resource mobilization.\
\
Billström highlighted the pivotal role of :abbr[MDBs] in achieving the :abbr[SDG]s. He asserted that :abbr[MDBs] are instrumental in innovating financing methods and mobilizing substantial finances, including private capital and domestic resources. Sweden supported the modification of the :abbr[MDB] business model to address global challenges more effectively, ensuring that poverty reduction and climate change remain central to their mission.\
\
Billström also highlighted the urgent need to mobilize climate finance from both public and private sectors, and to amplify support for local resilience and climate adaptation. Sweden pledged its continued commitment to adaptation and urged other nations to increase their contributions.\
\
Sweden underlined that human rights, democracy, and the rule of law are essential for development. Billström stated that the rights of women and girls, as well as :abbr[SRHR], are fundamental to development and are foundational for democracy.

sources.name: Sweden's National Statement at the 78th Session of the United Nations General Assembly

data.title: Japan receives calls to strengthen ODA commitment
data.content:
**On September 23, 2023, Japanese newspaper Yomiuri Shimbum called on Japan to strengthen its commitment to the :abbr[SDG]s, following Japan's appearance at the :abbr[SDG] Summit at the 78<sup>th</sup> :abbr[UN] General Assembly.**\
\
Global leaders used the summit to adopt a political declaration to push forward with policies aimed at achieving critical objectives, including the eradication of poverty, the promotion of quality education, and mitigation of the impacts of climate change. However, experts criticized the gaps between ideals and the realities of the challenges in the way of achieving the :abbr[SDG]s.\
\
Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida emphasized the importance of  :abbr[SDG] progress and urged nations to turn their shared ideals into actionable plans. He noted that despite the collective commitment to the :abbr[SDG]s, the world still faces poverty, hunger, and other issues. Kishida stressed that Japan, drawing from its extensive experience in development cooperation, should leverage its expertise to prioritize supporting stable livelihoods.\
\
Progress has lagged on the  :abbr[SDG]s, with approximately 30% of the goals associated with the primary objectives classified as either stagnant or regressing. The most pressing challenge remains the eradication of poverty and hunger, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa, where over 30% of the population still lives in extreme poverty. Efforts to combat these challenges face hurdles such as disruptions in grain exports associated with geopolitical conflicts, such as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, which have caused global food prices to rise and pushed many into food insecurity. Kishida noted that ending these conflicts is essential for the affected nations as well as for the broader global community.\
\
Japan’s history of development assistance has earned it a respected place on the global stage. To maintain its influence, Yomiuri Shimbum called on the Japanese government to strategically utilize :abbr[ODA] to secure necessary budget allocations. Furthermore, Yomiuri Shimbum noted that deepening collaboration with emerging powers could both serve Japan’s national interests and contribute significantly to global progress.\
\
As the Japanese 2024 draft budget is discussed by the Diet, Yomiuri Shimbum called for a strong focus on increasing the funding for and scope of :abbr[ODA]. The :abbr[SDG] Summit highlighted the pressing need for accelerated action. Japan’s experience and continued commitment is thought to be instrumental in addressing challenges on the path to a sustainable and equitable future.

data.title: Canada announces US$510 million in additional support for Ukraine
data.content:
**On September 22, 2023, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced CAD692 million (US$510 million) in new military, economic, peace and security, and development assistance investments for Ukraine.**\ \ The announcement was made during a visit to Canada by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. Trudeau reaffirmed Canada’s ongoing solidarity and unwavering support for Ukraine as it defends itself against Russia’s war of aggression.\ \ The funding from Canada included: - CAD650 million (US$479 million) in military assistance to supply Ukraine with 50 armored vehicles; - CAD8 million (US$6 million) in peace and security assistance to strengthen nuclear security measures, enhance resilience against cyberattacks, and promote recovery and stabilization initiatives; and - CAD34 million (US$25 million) in development assistance for four multi-year initiatives supporting mental health, agriculture, infrastructure, and technical assistance for an inclusive recovery process.
Trudeau and Zelenskyy also signed a modernized Canada-Ukraine Free Trade Agreement, which supports long-term security, stability, and economic development in Ukraine while ensuring high-quality market access terms for Canadian businesses participating in Ukraine’s economic recovery.\ \ The commitment brought Canada’s total to more than CAD9.5 billion (US$7 billion) in assistance to Ukraine since the beginning of 2022.

sources.name: Office of the Prime Minister of Canada

data.title: USAID announces US$23 million for TB
data.content:
**On September 22, 2023, :abbr[USAID] announced that it will provide an additional US$23 million to :abbr[USAID]'s Global Accelerator to End :abbr[TB] Plus funding package, where :abbr[USAID] has planned to spend a total of US$394 million in :abbr[FY]2023.**\
\
The funding will help reach the global targets that were agreed upon during the 78<sup>th</sup> :abbr[UN] General Assembly. The effort is slated to focus on a number of countries, including conflict settings such as Ukraine, Afghanistan, and Myanmar. It intends to deliver on new prevention and treatments efforts, reduce drug prices, and invest in innovations.\
\
:abbr[USAID] also pledged to commit 60% of :abbr[TB] funding to go directly to local partners by 2027.

data.title: EU Parliament calls for US$11 billion in MFF revisions
data.content:
**On September 20, 2023, the :abbr[EU] Parliament's budget committee approved a report calling for an additional EUR10 billion (US$11 billion) allocation to the bloc's Multiannual Financial Framework.**\ \ The Parliament's call for funding was an addition to the [Commission's June 2023 revision proposal](https://donortracker.org/policy_updates?policy=eu-commission-proposes-mff-revisions) totaling EUR66 billion (US$71 billion), which prioritized spending for Ukraine and addressing the root causes of migration.\ \ The additional funding proposed by the Parliament would be allocated in the bloc's Multiannual Financial Framework for the following budget lines: - EUR2 billion (US$2.1 billion) for addressing root causes of migration through development with non- :abbr[EU] partners, bringing the budget line total to EUR14.5 billion (US$15.5 billion) with the Commission's proposed additions; - EUR3 billion (US$3.2 billion) for strategic technological development within the :abbr[EU]; and - EUR5 billion (US$5.4 billion) for flexible assistance for humanitarian assistance and climate change, bringing the budget line total to EUR7.5 billion (US$8 billion) with the Commission's proposed additions.
The report is set to be voted on by the Parliament on October 4, 2023. Experts predicted pushback from Member States on the increased spending.

data.title: Sweden presents 2024 ODA budget
data.content:
**On September 20, 2023, the Swedish government presented its 2024 budget proposal to Parliament, which showed an approximately SEK56 billion (US$5.5 billion) allocation to :abbr[ODA].**\
\
Additional costs covered by the budget encompass assessed contributions to the :abbr[EU], :abbr[MFA] management costs, and in-donor refugee costs, which comprise 3% of the total budget with an 8% cap on the use of :abbr[ODA] to cover in-donor refugee costs.\
\
Sweden has exceeded the :abbr[UN] :abbr[DAC] target of 0.7% :abbr[ODA/GNI] since 1975. However, in September 2022, Sweden's then newly-elected right-wing government announced that it was ending the country's commitment to achieve 1% of its :abbr[ODA/GNI] and set :abbr[ODA] at SEK56 billion (US$5.5 billion) annually for 2023-2025, which is projected as approximately 0.88% :abbr[ODA/GNI].\
\
The budget lacked detailed information on specific allocations, but rather outlined general policy priorities. Sweden's international development cooperation priorities remain the promotion of Agenda 2030; poverty reduction; health initiatives for the most vulnerable; support for democracy aid to human rights defenders and champions of democracy; expanded and streamlined climate assistance; and women’s and girls’ rights and opportunities, including improved :abbr[SRHR].\
\
The 2024 :abbr[ODA] budget is slated to emphasize counteracting irregular migration, increasing repatriation, and contributing effectively to voluntary returns, as well as addressing the root causes of migration.\
\
Synergy between Sweden’s global trade, export promotion, climate, foreign, and :abbr[ODA] policies was another priority. Sweden named a single minister responsible for both development assistance and foreign trade. The government also emphasized the importance of promoting :abbr[ODA] effectiveness metrics in development cooperation.\
\
Ukraine remained Sweden’s main :abbr[ODA] recipient and priority, dedicating SEK6 billion (US$540 million) to Ukraine from 2023 to 2027. The Swedish government adopted a reconstruction and reform cooperation strategy with Ukraine on July 17, 2023, which included humanitarian assistance, financial backing, reconstruction initiatives, and support for civil crisis response capabilities.\
\
Global health remained a priority in the 2024 budget, with particular emphasis on the creation of societal conditions for good and equitable health for the most vulnerable. There was further emphasis on promoting health systems that are effective, sustainable, and resilient. Another area of focus included :abbr[SRHR] and improved preparedness and capacity to detect and manage outbreaks of pandemics, diseases, and other health threats. The budget emphasized that Sweden will continue its efforts to increase global vaccination coverage, including against :abbr[COVID-19].\
\
According to :abbr[OECD] data, Sweden’s total :abbr[ODA] to health in 2020 was US$594 million, making it the 9<sup>th</sup>-largest :abbr[DAC] donor in absolute terms. Sweden’s multilateral :abbr[ODA] to health represented 43% of its total health :abbr[ODA].

data.title: Netherlands announces 2024 development budget
data.content:
**On September 19, 2023, the Dutch cabinet announced that EUR400 million (US$428 million) will be cut from the 2024 development budget and reallocated to support the reception of asylum seekers in the Netherlands.**\
\
The 2024 budget showed an additional 7% of development funding will be reallocated to accommodate the high levels of asylum seekers in the Netherlands. The reallocation brings the total 2024 budget for the Minister for Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation to EUR3.6 billion (US$3.9 billion).\
\
In the budget announcement, the Dutch cabinet reaffirmed its foreign policy commitment to support Ukraine with humanitarian, military, and development assistance. Following the July 2023 collapse of the governing coalition, the cabinet committed to continuing its development agenda addressing the root causes of poverty, climate, terrorism and irregular migration, and achieving the :abbr[SDGs].\
\
Despite the cabinet’s commitment to continue existing development policy, the 2024 budget made cuts in addition to those announced in the April 2023 Spring Budget. The 2024 budget showed a cut of EUR300 million (US$326 million) to development funding, which contradicted the motion from June 2023 by the House of Representatives to reverse the April 2023 development budget cuts. The total amount of the development budget cut between 2023 and 2026 increased from EUR3.4 billion (US$3.7 billion) to a total of EUR3.5 billion (US$3.8 billion).\
\
Partos, which represents more than 100 development organizations in the Netherlands, criticized the 2024 budget. Director Liana Hoornweg argued that these cuts undermine the Netherlands’ international credibility, particularly in light of the Netherlands' recent call on other countries to contribute more to achieving the :abbr[SDG]s during the  78<sup>th</sup> :abbr[UN] General Assembly. Hoornweg called on the Dutch government to stop subsidizing the fossil fuel industry, which totals approximately EUR37.5 billion (US$40.8 billion) annually, and to reinvest those funds in sustainable development.

data.title: Norway presents action plan on gender equality, peace, security
data.content:
**On September 15, 2023, the Norwegian government published a new national action plan describing plans to intensify efforts to include women in peace and security work both domestically and abroad.**\ \ Minister of Foreign Affairs Anniken Huitfeldt emphasized the importance of gender equality and women's participation in peace and security work, both nationally and internationally. The action plan was prepared by the Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Defense, Justice and Public Security, Culture and Equality, Labor and Social Inclusion, and Climate and Environment. In addition, :abbr[CSO]s, Norwegian research institutes, and other experts provided input on the plan.\ \ The action plan listed three thematic priorities: - Peace processes and implementation of peace agreements; - Security policy and operations; and - Humanitarian efforts, protection of civilians and protection of human rights.
The plan noted that the women, peace, and security agenda will be emphasized in Norway's priority partners, which in 2023 were: Afghanistan, Colombia, Iraq, Jordan, Mali, Mozambique, Myanmar, Nigeria, Palestine, the Philippines, Somalia, South Africa, South Sudan, Sudan, Syria, Ukraine, Venezuela and Yemen.\ \ Regional and multilateral fora will also be prioritized, including :abbr[NATO], :abbr[OSCE], the :abbr[EU], :abbr[ASEAN], and the :abbr[UN].\ \ The action plan is slated to take place from 2023-2030. The Norwegian government described this timeframe as an effort to improve predictability and encourage a long-term strategic approach to an integrated implementation of the agenda. An interministerial review of the plan is slated for 2027.

data.title: Canada publishes UNGA attendees, topics
data.content:
**On September 14, 2023, the Canadian government announced that Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will travel to New York from September 19-21, 2023, to participate in the 78<sup>th</sup> :abbr[UN] General Assembly.**\
\
Trudeau announced his intention to advocate for enhanced international cooperation to address global challenges including climate change, security, democracy, human rights, access to health care, and financing for development. He also slated plans to reiterate Canada’s unwavering support for Ukraine as it defends itself against the Russian invasion.\
\
As co-chair of the :abbr[UN] :abbr[SDGs] Advocates Group, Trudeau announced his plan to speak at the :abbr[SDG] Summit, where he intends to emphasize Canada’s leadership and commitment to implementing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.\
\
Trudeau also announced plans to host a discussion in New York on how to improve international coordination and support to address the ongoing crisis in Haiti and foster sustainable development. Political instability, insecurity and armed violence, extreme inflation, and a cholera outbreak are currently worsening conditions in Haiti.\
\
The Canadian delegation to the General Assembly will include Minister of Foreign Affairs Mélanie Joly, Minister of International Development Ahmed Hussen, and Minister of Environment and Climate Change Steven Guilbeault.

data.title: Netherlands pledges US$2 million to Ukraine War Damage Register
data.content:
**On September 14, 2023, Dutch Minister of Foreign Affairs Hanke Bruins Slot announced EUR2 million (US$2 million) for the Register of Damage Caused by the Russian Aggression against Ukraine, located in The Hague.**\
\
The register is meant to record evidence to pursue future legal action against Russia. In addition to hosting the register, the Netherlands made a voluntary pledge to support the register’s operation and goals.
